Abstract
We introduce and describe the CHILES Continuum and Polarisation( CHILES Con Pol ) Survey, a 1000hr
1.4GHz wideband full polarization radio continuum deep/f_ield with the Very Large Array, commensurate with the
CHILES H I deep/f_ield. We describe the observational con/f_iguration, outline the calibration of the data, and
discuss the effect of radio frequency interference on different observing epochs. In addition, we present a novel
radio continuum imaging strategy, using well-known baseline subtraction techniques in radio spectral data, and
discuss the applications to the removal of artifacts from sources far from the /f_ield center. Additionally, we discuss
the nature of a low-level image-wide offset, the so-called “negative bowl,” and simulate our observations in order
that we may both properly understand and correct for this artifact. Using these techniques, we present the /f_irst
total intensity image of the data which achieves an rms noise of 1.3μJybeam
−1 with a synthesized beam of
4.5× 4.0, the most sensitiveL-band image ever taken at this resolution. We then place this image into the broader
context of 1.4GHz radio continuum surveys in the literature, in terms of image sensitivity and /f_idelity, andμJy
level source counts andP( D) analysis.
